ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes of learning
Discussions via Zoom
n/a

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I mainly learned how to improve my writing by learning how to write meaningful essays. It was also really useful to learn how to write a research paper.
I was able to improve my writing skills, learning how to formulate a strong claim and write a research paper.
I learned valuable lesson about how to improve my writing. Close analysis was something essential I took away from this class.
I now have a much better understanding of the foundations of writing and feel much more confident in my own writing.

I truly believe this class strengthened my writing skills by broadening the texts and other materials with which we crafted our papers. It also provided a nice introduction for me as a first year student to the discussion and seminar format of college classes.
I further developed my writing skills in a variety of contexts, mostly nonfiction. This class helped establish a good foundation for college-level writing.
Writing and critical thinking skills.
Critical analysis through close reading of different sources, ranging from films to dense scientific papers; how to write well-structured academic papers

Learning how to approach writing with many different styles. Learning how to read and get a deeper understanding of not only books but of articles and movies. Just overall becoming a better writer/reader.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: learning how to write essays in various styles, selected readings and films, peer editing
Weaknesses: sometimes the class discussions could be a bit dry, and although most of the readings were good, some were not very engaging

The discussions are really interesting! We watched films, read chapters from a self-help book, and read research papers. There are a lot of different genres and mediums explored in this class, and a lot of freedom in terms of the papers as well.

In depth descriptions and discussions of the texts and films we used were definitely a strength. However, a weakness was sometimes the conversation lulled because no one was willing to really expand on their ideas.

The wide variety of materials we read were interesting and helped develop our critical thinking  as writers and readers. Our engagement with multimedia was an enjoyable and helpful supplement. The only think I might add to the syllabus would be a fiction piece.

My professor did this, but I'm not sure if the others did so I'll put this here anyway: when there are deviations from the syllabus schedule, it'd be good to let students know clearly, such as using a Canvas announcement and directly editing the syllabus beforehand.

The strength was definitely the professor. Professor Dwyer structured this class so well given the online circumstances, and I looked forward to it every Monday and Wednesday. He laid out a clear plan for our class, but also kept it fluid and adjusted as necessary, which was very important for such unprecedented times. The content was also very engaging, the mix of readings and genres, as well as the occasional viewing material gave new dimensions to the class and generated some great discussion during our synchronous time. The writing assignments also had a nice variety, challenging my skills and strengthening my abilities as a writer. As far as weaknesses, I think every class is watered down by zoom, but obviously that's something we tried our best to overcome. I also think even more diversity in the readings would be interesting, such as the inclusion of poetry or some other "creative" texts that we could discuss.

A strength of this course was the organization! The theme of high school might seem odd, but it was a good way to reflect on the unique effects of the pandemic on life. It also pulled together seemingly disparate themes, but the course always keeps them in conversation with each other. Of course, ZOOM lectures can be tedious by nature. However, Seamus does a good job of guiding thought-provoking discussions!
Very engaging course with great articles.
Strengths: the amount of drafts and extensive feedback for each paper, Seamus made each class enjoyable and was super understanding
This class was amazing from beginning to end. The teacher taught well, the engagement was great as well as feedback.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the only main difference between this course during the COVID-19 pandemic and a normal year is that the class was over Zoom, so there isn't really anything that could've been done about that. We were placed in breakout room sometimes which helped us get to know our classmates during these unusual circumstances.

The online format worked well in this class! I felt engaged throughout the semester. The breakout rooms could be improved, but I've found that generally breakout rooms can be awkward regardless of the class.
It was difficult to work for 12 weeks straight with no break. In a class centered around essays, I thought it was necessary to have a break before moving to next essay.
Though this class was an online seminar, Seamus helped make it an engaging and productive medium. My classmates and I developed a good, collaborative rapport.
I think people were virtually engaged because the format of this course was a seminar, where people can't avoid having their cameras on and participating.

One activity that worked very well was the "annotate" feature on ZOOM. That way, we could mark up a document in real-time. I think that breakout rooms were also thoughtfully arranged and always had clear goals.
The professor did a great job with adjusting the course to fit the needs of online schooling.

The seminar format worked pretty well over Zoom, since it was a smaller group of students so discussion happened pretty freely. The workshopping with partners, both synchronous and asynchronous, was very helpful for paper-drafting. For other times, breakout rooms and discussion topics could have a little more structure to them just to facilitate better conversation.
Being flexible and open to the idea of the difficulties of virtual learning was a huge plus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. ENGL 114 in general is a great way to learn about college writing in a way that is not too demanding/rigorous. Take this course if you're interested in deeply reflecting on your high school experiences and learning new information about the high school experience in general.
Yes! It's such a great course to improve your writing, while also getting to explore topics that are interesting and particularly relevant.
Yes, learning about others high school experience was fascinating.
Yes! I improved my writing and thoroughly enjoyed my time in class.
Yes, it's a helpful intro level course.

100%, English majors and non-majors alike. Professor Dwyer makes the class incredibly engaging and comfortable, the readings and viewing material is diverse and interesting without being too easy or difficult, and it was my favorite class I took this semester hands down. We all went through high school to get here, and taking a deeper dive into that shared history with such an amazing professor was so enjoyable.

Absolutely! 100% recommend. Seamus is a wonderful teacher who provides clear, concise, and thoughtful feedback. The course was wonderfully adapted to suit online learning, and was definitely a highlight of my semester!
Easily one of my favorite courses. Very engaging material and an excellent professor.
Yes! Analyzing what the high school experience was more fun than I thought, and the class was a great introduction to college-level writing.
I would definitely recommend this course. The approach to learning is unique and very engaging. Overall just a great time learning.

extras.title:
ENGL 114 11
        What even was high school?
